articles.headline: Automakers Report Grim October Sales
articles.snippet: Facing tight credit markets and an economic slowdown, Ford, G.M., Chrysler and Toyota all reported selling far fewer vehicles than a year ago.
articles.abstract: Facing tight credit markets and an economic slowdown, Ford, G.M., Chrysler and Toyota all reported selling far fewer vehicles than a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Sales of new cars and trucks in the United States plummeted in October to levels not seen in the auto industry in 25 years.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Airwaves Battle Pits Dolly Parton Against Google
articles.snippet: The F.C.C. will vote on Tuesday on a proposal to make a disputed chunk of radio spectrum available for public use.
articles.abstract: The F.C.C. will vote on Tuesday on a proposal to make a disputed chunk of radio spectrum available for public use.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Tuesday marks the end of a battle that has lasted for more than two years, with each side predicting apocalyptic consequences should it lose.

articles.headline: Zaragoza, Beneficiary of Spain’s Heady Years, Feels the Undertow
articles.snippet: The experience of Zaragoza, the capital of Spain’s fastest-growing region, illustrates how the crisis is spreading beyond real estate and finance to fundamental sectors of the European economy.
articles.abstract: The experience of Zaragoza, the capital of Spain’s fastest-growing region, illustrates how the crisis is spreading beyond real estate and finance to fundamental sectors of the European economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZARAGOZA, Spain  Few places in Europe have prospered in recent years like this bustling crossroads city of 700,000, halfway between Barcelona and Madrid.

articles.headline: New Terrain for Panel on Bailout
articles.snippet: A committee of five little-known officials is picking winners and losers among institutions seeking a slice of the bailout.
articles.abstract: A committee of five little-known officials is picking winners and losers among institutions seeking a slice of the bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was a rare moment of levity at the Treasury Department on Friday as the children of government workers scampered from office to office in Halloween costumes. A few minutes later, the children were gone and the hallways were retaken by grim-faced grown-ups — handing out tricks and treats of a different sort.

articles.headline: Afghan Officials Aided an Attack on U.S. Soldiers
articles.snippet: A report found evidence of collusion between an Afghan police chief and the Taliban in an attack on the U.S. military.
articles.abstract: A report found evidence of collusion between an Afghan police chief and the Taliban in an attack on the U.S. military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An internal review by the American military has found that a local Afghan police chief and another district leader helped Taliban militants carry out an attack on July 13 in which nine United States soldiers were killed and a remote American outpost in eastern Afghanistan was nearly overrun.

articles.headline: Rein in Chief’s Pay? It’s Doable
articles.snippet: How to curb executive pay has become a hot-button issue now that American taxpayers are shareholders in the nation’s largest banks.
articles.abstract: How to curb executive pay has become a hot-button issue now that American taxpayers are shareholders in the nation’s largest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whoever is elected president on Tuesday, one hot-button issue from this long campaign will keep hounding Wall Street: executive pay.

articles.headline: The ’08 Campaign: Sea Change for Politics as We Know It
articles.snippet: The 2008 election has upended how presidential campaigns are fought, a fact almost lost amid the battle.
articles.abstract: The 2008 election has upended how presidential campaigns are fought, a fact almost lost amid the battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2008 race for the White House that comes to an end on Tuesday fundamentally upended the way presidential campaigns are fought in this country, a legacy that has almost been lost with all the attention being paid to the battle between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama.

articles.headline: Election Night Guide (Popcorn Included)
articles.snippet: What to watch for, from the first poll closings in Indiana to the last tossup state in the West, Nevada.
articles.abstract: What to watch for, from the first poll closings in Indiana to the last tossup state in the West, Nevada.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pundits and pollsters may be trying to take all the fun out of Election Day. So many have predicted a lopsided victory for Senator Barack Obama over Senator John McCain that you might wonder why even to bother watching the returns on Tuesday night.

articles.headline: Report Backs Palin in Firing of Commissioner
articles.snippet: A report released by a state board cleared Sarah Palin in the dismissal of her public safety commissioner.
articles.abstract: A report released by a state board cleared Sarah Palin in the dismissal of her public safety commissioner.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE  A report released on Monday by a state board found that Gov. Sarah Palin did not apply improper pressure to try to dismiss a state trooper who was her former brother-in-law and did not violate state ethics laws in the firing of her public safety commissioner.
articles.byline: By William Yardley and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Strongest Election Day Stock Rally in 24 Years
articles.snippet: Wall Street had its largest Election Day rally in 24 years as millions of American voters went to the polls.
articles.abstract: Wall Street had its largest Election Day rally in 24 years as millions of American voters went to the polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street built on recent gains Tuesday as reduced volatility and easing in the credit markets helped give stocks their strongest Election Day rally in 24 years.
